ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy

Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was a wonderful teaching assistant and really helped me grasp the topics that i didnt understand. His deeper insights into the topics made it easier to connect multiple theories.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy Menkhaus
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was helpful
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy Menkhaus
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Very friendly and helpful
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was great!
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  I interacted the most with Jeremy.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  I attended Jeremy's sections
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy Menkhaus
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy Menkhaus
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy and Zach
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was very helpful, patient, and deliberate in his explanation of the material.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Very relevant review sessions and helpful office hours.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun really clarified the topics from the class that i was not understanding fully and helped solidify my understanding.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Helpful discussion sections
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun Wang
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  WENJUN RULES!

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was the best! Her explanations were very clear and she is very patient. She was also the best at putting up notes from her discussion section online. She is a great teacher!!
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun Wang
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Very clear and explained concepts in a way that made the most sense out of any of the teaching fellows.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  I went to Wenjun's sessions about half the time
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was very helpful and very smart. Her discussion notes that were uploaded online were very helpful.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Thank you for your discussion sections!
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun is the best TA ever!
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Best TA I have had while at Yale-- wen jun was extremely helpful, clear, and friendly!
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wang, Wenjun - she was great! Very helpful, knowledgeable and friendly
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun Wang
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  See above.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was wonderful. Her commitment to our education was demonstrated by her section notes, and midterm and final study guides that she composed and posted to Canvas. She did an excellent job of explaining the course material and is obviously quite knowledgeable.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun Wang

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was a fantastic TA and critical for most of the class to grasp understanding the material. Her discussion sections (both office hours and structured sections) were always teeming with students. She was the only TA to create clear, concise study guides and upload them to Canvas. These materials were often critical to grasping the content since lectures were convoluted, unorganized, and unclear. WenJun's section notes were often the ONLY written guide to the models discussed in the second half of the course, given the lack of text book.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  I interacted with Wenjun over email and at her review sessions. She is so incredibly helpful, kind, responsive and always so happy to help with my learning. I really appreciated all her work.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was helpful
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zachary Turk
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I always go to his sessions on Friday. He is very friendly and helpful.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was a good TA. He explained things well and helped work through questions I had with the problem sets.

Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I found that the teaching fellows were inconsistent in their approach to grading. This would create instances where I would be graded down for something that had been acceptable for several weeks in a row. None them were wrong, per se, but we need to know what the expectations are. Please create consistency across TF standards in future grading.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I went to Zach's sessions about half of the time
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach is a great TA. I greatly benefited from his help sessions and found them to be more helpful than the course meetings for understanding our weekly assignments.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I attended Zach's office hours.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zachary Turk
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  What do you mean "identify"? Turk, Zachary
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zachary Turk
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zachary is a natural teacher. He was patient, methodical and explained the material in a clear, concise and easy-to-understand manner. His support was very helpful!
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Very relevant review sessions and helpful office hours.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  He explained concepts well and was very responsive
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Emphasized intuition in solving the problem instead of just relying on a graph.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Available to explain about the course
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  He was very accessible and helpful even outside of his office hours.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  I think Jeremy is a very friendly and approachable TA! He did a great job with the students this semester.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was an excellent TA! He was very approachable and helped explain tough concepts.

Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy was great. My general concern with the TA hours/section was that rather than guide us through a general review of material learned or questions we had, we were usually just guided through the solutions to the problem set. There is value in that, however, sometimes a query was a more general one, and not particular to the problem set, but you really had to push to get Jeremy to discuss/review a topic in general.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Great TA, always available and willing to help. His explanations really helped me learn the material.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  I did not attend his discussion sessions

Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Jeremy is able to explain concepts in a simple and clear way. I appreciated the time he took to explain the models and develop our intuition. He is a good teacher and makes sure students understand everything covered in the discussion section.

Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  Strengths: Jeremy was very helpful, patient, and deliberate in his explanation of the material. He was very available and supportive of the students. Weaknesses: I don't have any suggestions for improvement.
Instructor: Jeremy Michael Menkhaus  The few of his office hours I attended were good.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was outstanding and honestly taught me more in discussion sections than I learned in class. She was always clear and patient.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was AWESOME. She was very clear in her explanations and assistance in office hours. I also really appreciated that she posted her discussion session notes.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  She was very organized and gave the course a lot of context. However the discussion sections felt rushed and sometimes she didn't explain things when people weren't understanding. If approached individually, she was helpful.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Strong command of concepts and always available to help
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  She is very smart and good at explaining things.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was great about answering questions and explaining the material- she really knew the material well. She went very fast in discussion sessions though, I think there could have been clarity added by slowing down and allowing more time for us to ask questions throughout the lecture, instead of just at the end.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun is the reason I learned as much as I did in this class. I was able to attend her office hours and lecture section each week to really enforce what Kotchen had taught in class. I would not have been able to get through the problem sets without her. She devoted SO MUCH TIME and energy to the students! Really grateful for her amazing econ teaching skills.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun made a point to plan out her discussion sections every week, and the lessons were extremely clear and helpful! She is a great teacher! I would definitely take another class with her.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was amazing! She helps present the material in a way that was very understandable and memorable.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun is an amazing teaching assistant. She is great at communicating concepts in a variety of ways. She goes the extra mile to make sure that students have access to notes that clearly explain concepts.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun's discussion sections were super helpful reviews of the content. I also appreciated her effort to make up a review sheet for each week, which she posted online.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Helpful discussion leader
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Legendary discussion leader which often drew 25+ students to weekly review sessions. Powerful understanding of economics and ability to share that with us.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Really good discussion sessions. The only TA who posted her notes online, and this was very helpful for studying.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Quite organized and had a good understanding of the concepts in class
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Excellent TA!

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun is so patient, calming and such an excellent explainer, perhaps better than the professor himself. I am so stunned by how great of a teacher she is and she was one of the best parts of this class!
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Thought she did a great job-- would encourage all TAs to post notes from discussion as wen jun did.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  strengths: explains things very clearly, is helpful and pauses to answer questions weaknesses: a bit fast at times, can slow down a bit, but there is a lot to cover in a short amount of time - so great job! thank you!

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun is an excellent tutor that I really enjoyed working with. I rarely missed one of her sessions as she was an exceptional supplement to the class. She was very fair with grading, as well as being a wonderful tutor. She made excellent use of her time in tutoring sessions an in the discussion sessions so everyone could work together and there wasn't chaos. I truly think she will make a wonderful teacher following her education.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Strength: extremely organised discussion sections. Weakness: sometimes the discussion sections were too fast-paced.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Strengths: Wenjun was wonderful. Her commitment to our education was demonstrated by her section notes, and midterm and final study guides that she composed and posted to Canvas, which I greatly appreciated! She did an excellent job of explaining the course material and is obviously quite knowledgeable. I really appreciated all her help explaining questions that I struggled with on the problem sets. Weaknesses: My only suggestion would be to be more patient with the students as sometimes she would be noticeably annoyed with a question, making us feel embarrassed for asking it.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Her office hours were very helpful to understanding the problem-sets. The supplemental review classes she held were also useful, though I attended fewer of them.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was great. She came prepared for all discussion sections with an outline and summary of concepts, which she also posted on Canvas. She was friendly, patient, and really really nice during each office hours. Her room was always packed, and she did her best to help each group of students, often repeating herself multiple times to make sure we understood the questions.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  She was fantastic. The only way to improve would be to create more of her.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  I never actually went to office hours, but Wenjun posted very helpful notes on Canvas for all the major topics in the course.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Didn't interact much
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was great, very patient and unassuming. He always came prepared and was very helpful.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Good knowledge of the course
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  He knows his materials very well and he has simple ways to explains the problems. Nothing to be improved. His discussion sessions helped greatly.

Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was very helpful when answering specific questions that students had, but I would have found it helpful for him to also do overall reviews of the content covered each week.

Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was fantastic. My general concern with the TA hours/section was that rather than guide us through a general review of material learned or questions we had, we were usually just guided through the solutions to the problem set. However, it was clear that Zach's field of interest was economics of the environment and he was able to help explain concepts on which we were confused.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Accessible, patient, found his sessions to be most constructive.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I did not attend any of his sessions
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach was very kind and open to discuss economic issues - even if they are not related to the class.

Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Zach is a great teacher and knows the concepts really well. If not for the teaching assistants, I would have had a very hard time following and understanding the concepts from this course.
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Strengths: always approachable and patient with students. Weakness: none

Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  Strengths: Zachary is a natural teacher. He was patient, methodical and explained the material in a clear, concise and easy-to-understand manner. His support was very helpful! Weaknesses: I don't have any suggestions for improvement
Instructor: Zachary Michael Turk  I did not attend his office hours.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 13. Professor Kotchen was patronizing and arrogant. I didn't feel comfortable asking him questions, based on rude responses he made to other students.

Occasionally the professor would get turned around in his diagrams and it would confuse the class. Other than that, this class was extremely valuable. Kotchen is extremely approachable and although he would go too fast at times he was willing to break it down if you asked him to. Some of the readings towards the end of the semester went over my head.
Most of the semester was just pure economics and I understand that we need the basics, but I think not enough time was spent on environmental issues.
In general very good examples. And indeed very good at catching potential misunderstandings with inventing illustrative examples on the spot.
Professor Kotchen was not very approachable. I emailed him once over a lost homework assignment and he never directly responded to me or followed up with me about it.

While I enjoyed the material, I was rather annoyed at how many times Professor Kotchen would come to class not having reviewed his slides. He frequently drew graphs incorrectly on the board--I would say he made mistakes during a majority of classes. This was fine for those who understood already and could notice and correct the mistake, but it was utterly confusing for those who do not have a strong background in economics. I think this class would have been MUCH better as a flipped course.

I am so glad that I took this course ( even though some weeks with hard PS's and during the midterm and final study periods I was regretting it..!). Understanding economic concepts and environmental resource economics helped me in EVERY SINGLE other course this semester. Especially my Industrial Ecology Debate and my Climate Policy course. You really can't graduate from FES without taking this course or knowing these concepts.

Regarding question 13- Matthew was great at explaining the concepts throughout the course. However, I think my biggest struggle was how he would sometimes explain something incorrectly during class (drawing a graph incorrectly, or labeling parts of it incorrectly). I do most of my learning in class and with initial exposure to the material, so to learn and re-learn something during class was hard to do. I totally understand how confusing the subject matter is, so this is not a complaint. Matthew was a good lecturer. But I think learning something incorrectly and then having to go back through my notes to fix things afterwards hindered my understanding during lectures.

Kotchen tripped up on his lesson at least once per class. To students trying to learn introductory material that is brand new, this was frustrating. I went to a small, liberal arts undergrad and was just not used to professors who didn't prioritize their teaching. He clearly has a lot of other important responsibilities. However, he is a very funny and nice guy. Nothing personal!! Also he brought his son into the final exam and he was so adorable.

The class was well-structured as it went through the basics of econ theory and then how to apply that to environmental issues. It would have been interesting, though maybe a bit difficult to have some more structured discussions in class about current events.

My one suggestion is to include graphs and models in the Powerpoint slides, especially once the lectures and Mankiw text diverge. Accessing the slides on Canvas was very helpful in studying, thank you for doing those. However, they could have been even more helpful with models. Some days - especially when Kotchen had to erase his work several times and start over - my notes were hard to read, and verified guides would have been helpful. Mankiw provides this for the early lessons, but after that it's SOL. Also, it would be helpful - especially for those of us who are not economists - if the exams tested our ability to interpret graphs as much as they do our ability to create them. This would also be a better reflection of how many of us will use these skills. Thank you!
I wish we spent a little bit less time on the microeconomics (noted that it is very important) and a little more time on environmental economics.
Q.15) The course is helpful for any student who wants to pursue an introductory environmental economics course.

The course, while interesting, was far too simple for a graduate level course. I understand that not everyone has background knowledge of economics but it was simple to the point of unchallenging at times. It is a survey course, so there was a lot to cover in a short amount of time. However, if the instructor demanded greater comfortability with math, we could have really delved into more challenging aspects of the models than just the simplistic ways in which they were covered in this course. The problem sets were a good way to stay on top of the material and a great way to work through the topics learned in class. The professor is really good; he teaches and explains well. He always took the time to answer questions and review any aspects the students were struggling well. The strength of this class is entirely the strength of Professor Kotchen. He was engaged and fun to work with.

Great course. I would have appreciated more acknowledgement of uncertainty (barring our brief mention of it for MDF/MAC curves there was none). The truth is, our world isn't linear and modeling at such is an enjoyable intellectual experience but fails to capture the dynamism, despite its ability to establish a framework for the uninitiated. Numbers without pluses and minuses associated with them are meaningless to a study motivated by the scientific method. Acknowledging "Fat tails" and "black swans" would go far to enhancing this classes ability to explain the world and perhaps curtail some of the backrow economics haters' comments. An additional small suggestion: when releasing the keys, please preface the answer discussion with a repetition of the question. It doesn't take much effort but it sure is a pain to switch back and forth between pdfs on canvas. thank you, almost signed my name here.
Does not know the material he teaches. Avoids questions.

Overall professor Kotchen was enjoyable in the classroom. He was familiar with the material and was able to effectively answer almost all student questions. At some points we covered lots of material in a short time and I feel we could have benefited from a slower pace. His humor kept discussions light and I think he connects well with the students. He is very attentive so students in the classroom, which shows his caring nature and want for all to succeed.

This course was useful but sometimes too fast-paced for students without having any background in Economics. The microeconomics section was taught well and the concepts were covered thoroughly; however the switch towards environmental economics was daunting. Too many topics were covered within a short period of time making it difficult to grasp important concepts. Also, the midterm exam was too constrained on time and the ban of calculators during some lengthy calculations added to the difficulty.

Professor Kotchen is one of the best teachers I have ever had. I was nervous about taking the class since I had never taken an economics course before. However, the course is incredibly-well organized with reading materials and problem sets that are perfectly complimentary to the class discussion. The Teaching Assistants were available multiple times throughout the week to assist in clarifying the concepts and Professor Kotchen always posted his discussion slides prior to the lecture, allowing us time to prepare for the next class. While I greatly enjoyed the live lectures, I learned best from the recorded lectures that Professor Kotchen prepared one day in which he was absent from class. I found that Professor Kotchen spoke entirely too fast in class for me to understand, but the recordings allowed me to pause and rewind to ensure my understanding of the material. My suggestion would be to record the live lectures and allow students to go back and watch them or to please slow down in your explanation of the material!
The course lectures were very useful and typically clear. Occasionally the Professor Kotchen ran through the slides a little fast though.
Lectures were extremely unclear. Indeed, if a student's schedule did not allow time to attend Wen Jun's discussion sections, I'm not sure how this course would be navigable.

The course is an excellent introduction into economics for students in the environmental field. I particularly enjoyed the policy sections in the second half of the course. And Professor Kotchen is excellent!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Wenjun's discussion section
The lectures - they were well paced and interesting

I loved how the professor challenged the class. He would often explain what could be perceived as controversial statements and provide economic proof for making such claims. It was a refreshing dose of reality that many classes can lack in the environmental field. He was also very open to class discussions which were very interesting to follow.
I found the problem sets helpful
A lot of the concepts presented were presented in a fairly simple way, but still fairly powerful tools conceptually.
Professor Kotchen did a good job of providing interesting examples to go along with the theories.
Studying measuring Willingness to Pay
The best aspect of the course is that it provides pragmatic perspectives to environmental management strategies that are not talked by other courses in an economic context.

Lectures were lively and interesting. All basic economic concepts were explained using environmental examples, which was very helpful for keeping the material relevant to our studies. Overall a great intro to environmental economics.

Really enjoyed the early morning lectures -- kotchen is super entertaining (he resembles a young jerry seinfield) and you can just sit back, listen, take some notes, and enjoy his jokes...knowing that WenJun would explain it all again during her sections.
I really enjoyed the topics covered in the second half of the course (forests, fisheries, etc.). It felt very relevant and I appreciate that knowledge.
Gaining a strong understanding of environmental economics.
I liked the weekly homework, the concepts were easy to understand, the workload was perfect. Kotchen was very good at allotting time in class for questions/discussion.
The lectures are interesting and Kotchen is a very engaging lecturer.
While the problem sets felt like a drag sometimes, they really pushed me to figure out things on my own and learn the content.
Second half of the semester was the best and most applicable
The second half of the class was the most applicable to resource management and was the most interesting.
The class is quite interactive and the professor is very helpful and approachable.
The lectures for this class are very well taught, and the problem sets are great practice.
Professor Kotchen is by far the highlight of this course. He clearly enjoyed the material and cared about the student discussions that resulted.
Matthew Kochen gives great examples and always made sure to make the class interesting!

Exposure to important concepts and applications of microeconomics. Understanding of the 'economics' rationale or perspective towards environmental issues. Explains some of the real world conflicts I encounter.
The application of economic concepts in the environmental issues such as Forestry,Non-renewable resources,Pollution and Climate Change among other

Kotchen was a great professor despite the early class time. We discussed a range of information and being able to work in groups was extremely helpful both to understand the material and to work on team dynamics. I particularly liked the later section where we learned more about application.
Useful economic concepts were explained in a very clear and engaging way
meeting with other students to work through problem sets.
Assignments incentivize team work. There was always a group of people working on economic problems.

As someone who has never taken an econ course I felt the material was very appropriate for an intro/grad level environmental economics course. The power points all the way through were helpful but I also enjoyed how well the professor thought on his feet and was able to convey information on the blackboards.
Discussion sections by TAs.
The way it was organized with readings, problem sets, lectures and TA discussion sections. Students have every tool they need in order to succeed.
The course was my first introduction to economics, and proved to be a very useful tool for my other courses and interesting in its own right.

Kotchen was a very engaging professor, and I enjoyed this class the most. I felt like I was having a lot of fun each class learning about various concepts, which were always tied to real-life examples. I also really liked the problem sets. I liked working through them with my peers and reflecting on our lectures. They were sometimes painful to finish but altogether valuable for reinforcing what we were learning.
The lectures were always engaging and Professor Kotchen was so great at integrating student questions, real life examples and an interesting discussion into all lectures.
I really enjoyed Prof. Kotchen's teaching.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Professor Kotchen's attitude
The critical thinking - there was very little.

Many times the professor would get stuck or lost while making a point. This could be frustrating while taking notes in pen and while trying to comprehend complex points he is making. Sometimes I found myself asking "so what did he finally settle on as the right way to do it?" I also thought the microeconomics part moved a little too slowly at the beginning (I did take micro and macro econ in highschool so maybe that is why) while the pace at the end was a little too quick. Evening them out a bit could help. For the midterm and final, the ban on calculators didn't make any sense. We are tested on concepts, it'd be impossible to cheat and insert information into a calculator. That and unnecessarily quick pace for tests made it seem more like a high school class than conditions in which we would have to use economic concepts in the real world.
I think Kotchen could be clearer with his explanations- sometimes it was hard to follow. Also if you missed class there was really no material that matched what we did in class.
The section on non-renewable resources was odd. Not thorough enough to be really helpful in actual analysis, and yet quite tricky. Would consider removing, changing or something like that.

The mistakes Professor Kotchen would make when drawing the graphs was a serious problem because it led to a lot of confusion. I would have preferred to take a flipped version of the course because it would have meant there could be no mistakes in the lectures.
Nothing that I can think of.
TA's didn't communicate. Some would mark answers incorrect after another had said they were correct. TA Zach let people use calculators on the exam, while Kotchen had told us we could not.

It would have been interesting, though maybe a bit difficult to have some more structured discussions in class about current events. This would give students the opportunity to have more of their questions answered in class, instead of being brushed off as "off topic" or "use your intuition"

Wish we had the videos to watch for every class. That was very helpful being able to pause, and think, and replay. Wish Kotchen prepped some problems to go over for the final review session instead of making us come up with questions.

While the lectures are helpful at understanding broader concepts, they are not useful for answering the problem set/test questions. The book is awful and not helpful at all after week 3. The book selection could really be improved.

They last few weeks of the class moved really fast for me, and at points I felt like I'd lost the overall point of what we were doing in order to focus on the details. Each time we begin looking at a new model I think it would have been helpful to spend more time discussing the overall point of the model and why it's useful. In a few cases I didn't really figure that out until the problem set or exam studying.
Sometimes material was presented incorrectly and this was very confusing. Notes should be consulted more frequently.
The graphs that are discussed in class should be included in slides so that students can refer to them later.

Throughout the semester, many of my classmates expressed interest in discussing economics while considering socioeconomic disparity and environmental justice issues. Each time these questions arose in our course meetings, Professor Kotchen failed to answer them. I do not believe there was a genuine attempt to make this course realistic to the environmental challenges we will face as professionals in this field. I do not foresee myself taking any further economics courses and believe this course could do a better job of incorporating discussion of challenges impacting the theoretical frameworks in the future.

The difficulty of the course needs improvement. Also providing additional material on the graphs. Professor Kotchen would explain the graphs on the board (the slides didn't contain graphs) but it would have been useful to have some material to review in conjunction with the notes I took (just to clarify parts).
I think the class went a bit faster than necessary, it was hard to keep up sometimes.

I generally like Prof Kotchen's teaching style. In class he is charismatic, clear, responsive and he expects the best from the students. But sometimes his (unmet?) expectations makes his comments come across as patronising.
Seems like there is a lot to cover within a short period of time.There could be ways to split it to ensure a better grasp of the concepts than just rushing though.
I'd like to see even more application and a greater range, if possible. I thought this was very helpful.
The office hours and discussion sections should be in bigger rooms! It was stressful and crowded to be in the tiny kroon basement rooms for Wenjun's office hours.
The course was based mostly on graphical illustrations. Perhaps it would be useful to dive more into the numerics and equations too.

I think it would be good if students are asked to take Microeconomics basics before they join the program (or maybe a week before/after MODs). This course could then be dedicated to just environmental economics, instead of spending half the course learning the basics in an accelerated manner (which might not work well towards greater understanding of the material).

I thought the wording of some questions on p-sets and tests was a bit confusing and could be clearer. The pace near the end of the class was also fast. It would also be helpful to get p-sets in word doc form.
Lesser topics can be covered in greater detail.

I thought that Professor Kotchen spoke too fast for me to keep up with the lectures. I would encourage him to slow down and repeat and/or emphasize certain important points to make sure students don't miss those.
I felt a lot of this course moved very slowly.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The discussion sections were very effective at helping students understand the material. I thought Zach did a great job. I couldn't go to Wenjun's discussion sections, but I heard from others who went to them that they were even more helpful than class.
Yes
Very effective!
Discussions were very helpful, both for understanding the material taught in class and for help with the weekly problem sets.
Repeated exposure helped. However, all but one discussion section overlapped with a class so I didn't get much time with the TAs.
The TAs led discussion section and they were very helpful fr reviewing the material covered that week in class.
The discussion sections were very helpful. The teaching assistants did a good job of making themselves available for questions.
The discussion sections were a helpful addition to the class. I found them most useful when I'd completed my problem set before going. As such, the later in the week they can be scheduled the better!
The TAs did a great job in ensuring that the sections are relevant to the course content.

The sections were usually catered to working through the problem set. It would have been helpful if we went through additional examples but usually there was one example related to the topic in lecture and then the problem set.
Three separate discussion sessions available each week with the TAs and then office hours for all three plus the professor, there was lots of opportunities!
I never went to discussion / lab because none of them fit in my schedule. It would've been nice to be able to go to them.
The discussion/lab sections are absolutely necessary. They greatly help understand the concepts covered in class.
I really only attended Wenjuns sessions but the relationship was excellent. Material being taught coincided very well between the class and the discussion sessions.
N/A
Yes. Wenjun did a great job reinforcing lecture content in her discussion sections, which were very well-attended.
They were well related, the TAs always covered topics that they thought students would need to review after the lectures. It was a very well integrated course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in business and the environment and this class was crucial to continuing my business education
It fits the programme well as a key aspect of Natural resources
I wanted to gain an overview of environmental economics to inform the rest of my studies (urban planning and urban ecology).
A vital foundation course for your FES years
Adds to my quantitative skill set.
I am very interested in markets and investments and how they apply to the energy sector.
Good foundation to economics for other future courses.

I am interested in Economics and wanted an introduction to the field of Environmental Economics. This course has helped me gain more clarification on which specialisation I might want to choose in the future.

While I had taken a few courses in economics in my undergraduate level I had not explored the interactions between microeconomics and the environment and how the same lead to formulation of policies by the government or the relevant institutions.Taking this class gave an insight of how tradeoffs are made when it comes to environmental conservation among other things.
Provides a useful basis from which to construct arguments in favour of sustainability from an economic perspective

As a student who had not taken economics, I think this class was very important and an excellent option for a foundations course. Timing was appropriate as well to take professor Gillingham's energy economics course.
Overall a very useful introduction to students having no background in economics.
This course is an absolute must. It provides the tools to understand the way the world works, which is necessary for anyone trying to make meaningful change.

I had never taken an Econ class before this, so I am happy to now have an understanding of microecon and environmental economics, especially since I plan to pursue something policy or management related. Economics really does come into play in nearly every situation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To become literate in economic concepts
I wanted to learn some foundational economic theory
I am interested in energy finance and this was a good primer for the field of economics.
Seemed like a good way to get a basic econ course and at the same time understand some specific environmental policy cases - and did indeed do exactly that.
It's a useful course for learning more about economics.
Interest in the subject matter.
Needed to improve my skills on valuation of Natural resources
I never had an econ class before, and I think this is a great way to see environmental management through a different lens.
I wanted to learn economics.
I had very little economics exposure before this class and I needed and wanted to learn basic economic principles.
Wanted to have a better understanding of economics.

It's a foundation course, and as one of my goals with this degree is to round out my scientific literacy and interdisciplinary knowledge, I trust the school in knowing what courses to suggest as foundational.
I am interested in policy, so a strong foundation in economics is essential.
My adviser told me to.
To gain a broad understanding of the methodologies used in economic analysis in order to better understand the work done by researchers in this field (both its utility and failings).
I wanted to have a strong foundation in economics because I plan to take other economics courses in the future at FES.
- Appropriate workload. - Interest in Environmental Economics.
I wanted to challenge myself and thought economics was an important training opportunity.
I took this course to get a solid foundation of environmental economics. I plan to take more economics classes, and this class taught me the basics.
I wanted to try a field in economics that I was unfamiliar with.
I thought it was important to get a basic understanding of economics for my future career, even though I do not plan to use it actively in my career, but I know it will be important as some points.

For someone focusing on corporate sustainability I felt this course would help decipher some of the dichotomies between economics and environment I found in my work. I felt I needed a better foundation of economics and how it is applied in solving environmental issues.

I decided on this course in order to understand the role of economic evidence in advocacy for environmentally related cases.Further, statistical facts tend to have an attraction to people hence the need to understand how this is arrived at,but more to understand how markets behave under different conditions.
Understanding the economic case for sustainability is extremely important. I also had limited econ exposure during my undergraduate experience.
Economic concepts are critical to understand how decision are made.
to gain a better understanding of economics particularly as it relates to the environment
I took the course because it offered some important tools/skills I felt I was missing from my previous education.
To get an introduction to Economics which would create a firm foundation for environmental policy-making.
I didn't take economics in college and felt that it would be important.
I had never taken economics, and sought to remedy this.
I had taken resource economics courses, but I really wanted to have some practice working through problems.
I had never taken an Econ class before and wanted the understanding moving forward.
In order to learn about the environmental aspects of economic discipline.

I don't have an economics background. I was surprised to find that a lot of the concepts were things I knew from other places - specifically, I was familiar with many of the concepts from the YLS class Property, Social Justice, and the Environment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes
Yes
Didn't have many expectations.
Ok
Yes. It absolutely did.
Yes, very well!
Yes
Yes
Yes
I feel more confident with the material and I look forward to taking more economics classes in the future.
Yes.
Yes, I believe I gained a solid foundation in this area.
Yes
I was expecting the approach to be a bit more quantitative and rigorous.
No. I am not confident in my understanding of the course material and struggled throughout the semester.
Yes, very much so.
I would have preferred a more challenging course; as a survey course it was great, I got a general idea of the different models used and the different areas of interest within in the field.
Yes
Yes it met my expectations.The class evolved from simple concepts of supply and demand to discuss how different factors such as government regulations can influence emissions in a given state.
Yes
Absolutely.
yes! thank you!
Mostly.
More than exceeded my expectations. This was by far one of the best classes I've ever taken.
Yes
Yes!
Yes.
Yes!
I felt the course moved slowly; I wish we had had time to go into more advanced economic theory.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to bounce ideas off of each other and learn together.
Just easier to do on own.

in this course, if you work alone, it takes a lot longer than it should. Working in groups makes you engage in discussions that are very meaningful for not only solving the problems but understanding them.
Did some PS work and Studying in groups, which made it fun.
I often worked in groups on my problem sets. These were very helpful for bouncing ideas and gaining a better understanding of the materials covered in class.
We worked in groups on the Problem Sets each week and it was very beneficial to my learning.

There was no formal group work, but I had a consistent group of people to go thorough problem sets and review some of the challenging topics of the course with. I found it very helpful and highly recommend this approach.
N/A
Made the content more accessible, bolstered group dynamic skills, great class to take as a first year to get to know your classmates better
Group work was great - definitely take advantage of other students.
My classmates were able to answer most of my questions.
Collaborative learning is always good - I enjoyed learning from my classmates and their support.
I felt that working in groups on the homework was very helpful, the homework was challenging and much easier to figure out with a few minds. I made many friends just from working on the p sets.
Group work was incredibly advantageous for the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Put away concerns about equity to get through this class
Take it

If really keen on getting into some gritty maths this is NOT the course. If you are really keen on getting acquainted with a fairly wide range of econ. concepts with relevance to environmental challenge and qualifying some of the at times fuzzy environmental argumentation then this is your course.

The problem sets are a time commitment, but they are only once a week so it is definitely manageable. The exams are challenging. The book is helpful for the first half of the semester and can be borrowed or purchased for $5 on amazon. You can probably get away with skipping the readings.
Anybody who is in the field of environmental management should definitely take this course. There was not much math involved, so don't worry if your math is as rusty as mine.

Definitely take it! It is a perfect introduction to economics, with an environmental focus, plus a look into the basics of environmental economics. Economics are becoming incredible important in environmental policy decisions, so this class is a great way to understand why many decisions are being made.
Take it if you have never studied economics before or would like a refresher.
Its a good class that will leave you with practical and applicable skills.
Take the course. I changed the way I think about policy and potential solutions to environmental problems.
Helpful if you are interested in valuing resources and pollutino

Stay engaged at all points throughout the semester as the content builds on itself. I would also recommend working on the problem sets alone, and then meeting up with others in order talk through the topics you don't understand later. I found that the challenge of working through a problem set myself was extremely helpful to solidifying my understanding.
Work in groups for the problem sets. It helps a lot to think through the concepts with other people.
Great course for students who want to gain a broad view on Environmental Economics.
I would definitely take this class. It is very well taught, and the workload is appropriate and helps you learn the skills taught in the class.

Take the class if you have no previous training in economics- Professor Kotchen does a great job of quickly working through micro fundamentals. However, if you have previous economics experience, this will likely be a little too easy. It is definitely a great survey course to figure out particular areas of interest within the field, but may not be the most academically challenging course available.
Be ready to do some hard problem sets, work in groups, and take advantage of the teaching assistant's discussion questions and office hours. Kochen is a great professor!

If you are someone without much economics background, you will probably find the lecture sessions insufficient. I definitely struggled in a few of the lecture sessions. Only through extra time spent going through the materials on my own, TAs and self-formed study-group was I able to get a better grasp of things. Be prepared to invest some time.
The course is quantitative and may require extra hours for those who do not have a background in economics or heavily quantitative courses.
Take it!
take it!
Don't miss classes and do the assignments!
Attend the TA sessions.

My biggest piece of advice for any class really is to show up and pay attention. Very important in this class as there are no supplemental videos. I think everyone really enjoyed the couple of recorded classes that were offered.
Attend the discussion sections.
Do NOT miss out! This course is an absolute must.
It is a useful course if you've never taken economics, want to brush up on the introductory topics, or want to understand environmental components of economics.
Work together on problem sets. But study with no more than one person.
The course provides critical economic skills and exposure to important concepts. Take the course, but have an exceptional study group and ensure time to attend section and office hours.
It's a solid and well-taught background on microecon. If you want the background in it, take it. Kotchen is a good professor who makes the subject accessible.
This course gives you a much needed economic background into the environmental field and will be useful no matter what your focus is!
